function_call.name: classify_risks_PESTLE
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Longevity of sars-cov-2 on surfaces, leading to prolonged exposure risk.","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Potential spread of the virus through airborne aerosols and droplets on various surfaces","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Graphene oxide go and reduced graphene oxide rgo contain oxygen functional groups hydroxyl, carboxyl, carbonyl, and epoxy that affect their physicochemical properties.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Increased number of graphene layers can weaken the antimicrobial activity and cause increased aggregation tendency.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Graphene derivatives with antimicrobial properties","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Cytotoxicity of graphene derivatives due to negatively charged groups","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Risk of promoting graphene derivatives as a primary solution for virus destruction","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Sharp edges of graphene nano-walls inactivating bacteria and viruses, leading to potential reduction in survival rates.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Surface modifications of graphene influencing antimicrobial activities and antiviral properties.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Agglomeration causing weakened dispersibility and adsorption capacity of graphene, reducing efficacy against microorganisms.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Improper dispersion of nanomaterials like graphene and mnps may lead to reduced antimicrobial activity, allowing pathogens to spread","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate sterilization of frequently used surfaces can lead to continued risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Debatable antimicrobial mechanism of graphene materials","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Use of unproven materials for antiviral applications","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Variability of biocidal activity of graphene-based materials","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Use of metal nanoparticles in high-performance coatings may pose a risk of environmental contamination and toxicity.","category":"Environmental risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Challenges related to poor solubility and processing of graphene oxide go may hinder the fabrication of antimicrobial coatings.","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Transmission of rna and dna viruses","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Ineffective antiviral composites","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Dependence on concentration and exposure time","category":"Public health risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Exposure to graphene family materials with antiviral properties","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Modification of properties using polymeric material and mnps","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Mechanism of action of gbns against viruses","category":"Technological risks","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Gbns penetrating cell membrane for physical
